comments.commentBody:
I was going to go out to all the local clubs tonight, but then saw this was a Brad Wilber puzzle, so I convinced my wife to stay home. That's my story, and I'll stick with it.

Great challenge with some wonderful clues; record producers for arrests could have been the best. Abductor of the Sabine women? Wasn't that Howard Keel and his seven sons? Who's this Romulus guy?

SULTANS HOTEL

I have visited Istanbul before and knew I wanted a hotel close to the centre of the Old City with the Blue Mosque etc in easy walking distance. It could not have been easier than this! The location is perfect for hitting the main historical attractions and also only a short walk down to the ferries for the Bosphorus cruises.

The staff were helpful and polite. We were picked up by airport transfer in a very grand car and the rooms were clean and pretty. Ours had a large balcony too. Sometimes the shower water was a little tempremental but aside from that it was perfect!

If you are in Istanbul for the weekend then this is the perfect place as its close to everything you'd want to see and the staff really help you out.

My top suggestion for Istanbul is to visit the Blue House Hotel's roof terrace. Its the highest point between the Blue Mosque and Haigha Sophia and the staff are super-helpful and friendly. Go at sunset, order a pipe and a beer and some little tapas bits and watch the sun set over the Bosphorus. A little slice of pure happiness. Right there.
R?CHARD

I couldn't have completed the solution without the hints FRIGHTWIG (I kept thinking of hats and FLOWERPOT) and FUN.  I had IDOLIZE for 38D for much too long. This was very, but appropriately, challenging for a Thursday puzzle, and I enjoyed it.

As parts of this puzzle had me B.Wilbered, I just popped in for some pointers.

One might think that doing the puzzle with Anderson Cooper and Kathy Griffin talking over each other in the background would be helpful, but no. There were many shots of people in Times Square wearing Ads, and at 9:00 Western Coast Standard Time some Ball "dropped". . .actually it looked like it was consumed by a giant Toshiba number-spewing scaffold Ad. There was a shot of Mayor Bloomberg standing next to a Nivea Ad, while John Lennon sang "Imagine no possessions. . . ". All truly inspirational stuff.

Unlike the puzzle, it's easy if you try.

I gave up my 50 yard line upper deck season tickets years ago because I got tired of being surrounded by drunken bozos behaving badly -good move no beer Sunday night, but it will not help -they will get blotto in the parking lot before the game

It didn't take long after I started to read your article for the eyes to well up with tears. In fact, about half way down the page I was worried that someone would notice -I was sobbing like a child. You have a significant gift that enables you to demonstrate what it means to be a man and more importantly, what it means to be a dad. Thanks for using words to describe honest relationships with the ones you care for the most. My kids are older now but once a dad always a dad. To this day, I believe I carry them and still can't help looking at the world through their eyes.

I admire your ability to see your kids for who they are and I admire you for the service you gave to my country. God Bless you, Lee -and your kids.

This is a wonderful story; thank you for sharing..  Your love for your family is so evident and the way you look through your children's eyes is inspiring.  Happy New Year and wishes for joy and prosperity are sent to you.

Nice essay Captain!

Duh! Did I miss something? Where is your wife in your graditude to be home?

Bravo for a wonderfully warm essay! As a board member of a child advocacy nonprofit, I believe children are indeed close to God -- whether he or she is a child in America, China, Sweden, Brazil, or Afghanistan.

Sincerely,
Thomas Huynh, founder
Sonshi.com

Thanks for your service, Captain. It sounds like your kids have a good father. Congratulations.

I have concerns for the families of the soldiers and marines who are making repeated deployments to the combat zone. They and their loved ones in uniform are the only Americans we have asked to make any sacrifice in our nation's current wars. I find that unconscionable, and blame our past and present gutless politicians.

I absolutely loved this!  What a great story about an honerable man and his great family.  You may as well have subtitled this: Life View of a Man With His Head Screwed On Straight.  It sounds like you are finally, thnkfully, where you need to be.  God bless you and yours in this New Year.
Thank you for your piece and for your dedication to country.  You represent everything that makes me proud to be an American.  Happy New Year!
Welcome home...it's amazing that our children don't ever realize how much they are carrying us...with their love and love of life.
Thank you for your service and your beautiful essay. Your words give me something positive to reflect on during this New Year's Eve.
So moving and touching. Thank you so much, and happy new year to all!

Thank you for your service and your children have a hero to look up to. On Veterans day I stood in front of my church and talked about veterans and the last statement was that looking at the children in the church is what I fought for--their freedom.

Wow--your story is very moving.  Thanks for sharing!   Our country is lucky to have gentle soldiers like you, and I wish that all of our nation's youth had loving fathers and homes like yours.  As a 24 year old daddy's girl myself, I know that nothing is as comforting as a father's secure embrace, knowing he'll take care of you.  In this next year of 2010, I hope to take care of more other people around me in the same way, with commitment, patience, and love.
Heartwarming. Just what I needed for New Year's eve.

"Love is what makes you smile when you're tired."

Terri - age 4

I just want to say how much I admire Captain Kelley for his efforts to view the world through his children's eyes, to change his perspective after his deployment in the war. I think you are on the right path, Captain Kelley--God bless you and your family!

In your next piece perhaps you can address the impact our war on Iraq has had on Iraqi families and children. They're humans too.

I write this on a day that a judge threw out charges against US military contractors who shot 17 Iraqis civilians dead and left about 20 wounded. This contractor, Blackwater (recently changed it's name to XE) continues to be employed by the US Government.
Beautifully expressed. And as a 37 year-old woman, I can relate to Chloe's love of office supplies.  Loved it as a kid, and still do!

I do read this blog from time to time, but it is painful for me as Mom to a soldier. He spent eight months in Iraq this year. He is home now, and I watched as he spent his day today putting together his uniform for a night on the town with his girl (smart, loving, and beautiful  who works in a VA hospital while working toward a degree in physical therapy). But before the New Year is out, he will be in Afghanistan. My thoughts are with the families of every soldier separated from their families this holiday season, and my heart fills with joy for every one of you who can enjoy this time with family and friends. God bless and Semper Fi.

So I just realized that most people who read my post about my Marine son's girlfriend working at a VA hospital will think I'm making it up. Sometimes truth is stranger than fiction. What else can I say?

Believe in this war, or any other war (or not), every citizen should be thaknful that we have stand up men like Lee Kelley in our country. I have never served, and in general, don't believe in war, but without men like Lee, our country would not be what it is today. As a father myself, I feel that it is probably just as important to be a strong parent as it is to fight for your country. Thank you Mr Kelley, I salute you!!!

sg
